Quoted from the Objectivist Lexicon on the ARI website: Quote Philosophy studies the fundamental nature of existence, of man, and of man’s relationship to existence. As against the special sciences, which deal only with particular aspects, philosophy deals with those aspects of the universe which pertain to everything that exists. In the realm of cognition, the special sciences are the trees, but philosophy is the soil which makes the forest possible. “PHILOSOPHY: WHO NEEDS IT” Philosophy: Who Needs It, 2

Not any in particular! Instead, we should see philosophy as the thin edge of science. Philosophy can be wrong and has been wrong on many things, but it sets the standard below which there is no science. I think the most important contribution of philosophy is to open new territories for investigation. Initially, it may be difficult to do any hard science on it, but just talking about it as rationally as we know to do it, and philosophy certainly does that, is a good way to prepare the ground for some science. Short of that, all we have is common sense and religion. Talking about a subject is the best way to get people interested and to get them to try and do something that will be good enough to make the philosophy of it obsolete. That being said, the closer to metaphysics we get, the less likely science will ever have anything to say about it, questions such as the “nature” of subjective experience. Because of this, philosophy will always have something to talk about. Whether it may be really useful may be itself a philosophical question.
